-- public async Task Foo() {
    -- ... // Part A
    -- await Moe();
    -- ... // Part B
    -- }
Would you please help me with understanding your explanation of async? 

You say:
Await takes a single argument, an awaitable (an “awaitable” is an asynchronous operation, in our case, I suppose, the "Moe" method).

Await examines that awaitable to see if it has already completed:

           -- if the awaitable has already completed, then the method just continues running (synchronously, just like a regular method). QUESTION 1: HOW COULD IT HAVE ALREADY COMPLETED, IF IT'S THE FIRST TIME WE ARE CALLING MOE()?

           -- if “await” sees that the awaitable has not completed, then it acts asynchronously. It tells the awaitable to run the remainder of the method (DOES THE REMAINDER MEAN THE "PART B"??) when it completes, and then returns from the async method (DOES RETURNING FROM THE ASYNC METHOD MEAN THE RESULT OF AWAIT MOE()?)".
Thank you.
